appropriations: The Judiciary testimony requests $9.9M (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) in bond funds for capital improvement projects in FY 2026. A subsequent committee hearing recommends that the Committee on Finance consider authorizing an additional $2,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_) specifically for the relocation of the Children's Justice Center. This differs from the previous note which presented the combined total as a final appropriation.
economic_impact: Testimony requests a $1,000,000 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) increase to the budget line-item for statewide civil legal services to address the unmet legal needs of low-income residents. The funding would support providers like the Legal Aid Society of Hawaii and Volunteer Legal Services Hawai‘i. This specific monetary request was not detailed in the prior fiscal note.
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary testimony requests capital expenditures totaling $9.9M (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) in FY 2026, which includes $4.0 million (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) for a new South Kohala District Courthouse design and $5.0 million (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) in lump sum funds. The House Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs report recommends adding $2,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_) to the lump sum funds to cover costs for relocating the Children's Justice Center. This brings the potential lump sum amount to $7,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_).
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary update from the previous fiscal note involves clarifying the status of the Capital Improvement Project (CIP) funding. This note specifies that the Judiciary's request is for $9.9M (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_), with a subsequent committee recommendation to consider adding $2,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_), rather than treating the total as a finalized appropriation. Additionally, this note incorporates the specific request from legal aid organizations for an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_) for civil legal services, a detail not previously included.

Capital Improvement Project (CIP) requirements continue to remain a major item of 
concern as the Judiciary’s infrastructure continues to age and deteriorate, and as the population 
served and services provided by the Judiciary continue to expand. We request CIP bond funds 
totaling $9.9 million for FY 2026 to address critical needs, some of which relate to the health and 
safety of Judiciary employees and the public. Specifically, the Judiciary is requesting $4.0 million to design a new South Kohala District 
Courthouse.

Comments:  
Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony in strong support of the Judiciary Budget, HB 
400. I am very supportive of the Judiciary and all of the work that they do in and for our 
community. I am also very much in support of the current line item in the budget that supports 
funding for civil legal services (currently funded at $1.2M), but would respectfully request 
that the amount be increased by and additional $1M. Having worked on civil legal service provider funding for many years, I am aware that civil legal 
service providers are chronically underfunded. With all the uncertainties at the federal level, this 
funding is more critical than ever. Legal service providers are often the last line of defense 
protecting individuals from eviction, deportation, homelessness, family separation and other 
barriers to basic survival in our community.

With respect to the line item for funding in the Judiciary budget, the purchase of services funding 
the Legislature has provided was historically for statewide general civil legal services, but under 
the current Judiciary criteria is now open to all civil legal services providers. This has ultimately 
diluted critical safety net funding, so we are asking for a $1M increase to support the critical 
work that these organizations provide. To be clear, I do not want our request to supplant any of 
the Judiciary's other priorities, but respecfully ask that consideration be given to this request for 
an increase in legal service providers funding. Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony in strong support of this measure. Mihoko Ito

TESTIMONY IN SUPPORT OF H.B. 400 
RELATING TO THE JUDICIARY 
Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs – January 30, 2025  2:00 p.m. CHAIR TARNAS, VICE CHAIR POEPOE AND MEMBERS OF THE COMMITTEE ON 
JUDICIARY & HAWAIIAN AFFAIRS:   
  
Volunteer Legal Services Hawai‘i supports the passage of H.B. 400. This critical funding would go to funding civil legal services, including but not limited to the 
delivery of civil legal services to low- and moderate- income individuals in Hawai‘i. Volunteer Legal is pursuing a one million (1,000,000) dollar increase in funding for the civil 
legal services line item for providers. The civil legal services line item was initially intended for 
statewide general civil legal service providers. Other important legal service providers are now 
accessing the funding, and we anticipate that more will apply.
